main event: On January 11th, 1959 in Farewell, Alaska, a bright light was observed to the west of the observer's stationery, then moved to the northwest and disappeared, possibly into or behind a cloud. The observation lasted for one hour.
interesting points: The bright light was observed for a duration of one hour, exhibiting movements varying from reddish to bright white with erratic and rapid vertical and horizontal movements.
The report suggests several possible explanations including British Balloon, Satellite, Aircraft, Astronomical, Balloon, Space Debris, and 'Unknown'.
The object was noticed by the airman and was described as exhibiting erratic movements such as lazy-eights and circles before disappearing into or behind some clouds.
The object was estimated to have an altitude of 35,800 feet and was observed by various credible witnesses including the Alaska Air National Guard and an insurance salesman.

Observers were emphatic that the object was not a reflection on the windshield or an aircraft, and both the aircrew and ground sighting corroborated that it was not an aircraft due to extremely smart maneuvers.
witnesses: Alaska Air National Guard, airman, ground observer, and various other credible witnesses
